questions.text: A farmer presents with an ulcerative skin lesion with central necrosis. A smear from the lesion, stained with polychrome methylene blue, shows capsulated bacilli positive for the M'Fadyean reaction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical vignette of an ulcerative lesion with central necrosis, along with visualisation of capsulated bacilli positive for the M'Fadyean reaction on staining with polychrome methylene blue, is suggestive of Bacillus anthracis.

  • Bacillus anthracis, the cause of anthrax, primarily affects herbivores, and humans acquire infection through contact with infected animals or products, ingestion of contaminated material, inhalation of spores, or injection.
  • These are spore-forming gram-positive bacilli with a poly-D-glutamic acid capsule.
  • This capsule is distinctive as, unlike most bacterial capsules made of polysaccharides, it is composed of protein.
  • Cutaneous anthrax, the most common form, develops at the site of spore entry into injured skin, forming a painless lesion that progresses to a black eschar and may lead to systemic infection.
  • Inhalation anthrax, also known as Wool-sorters disease, has an incubation period of up to six weeks, presenting with mediastinal oedema, haemorrhage, pleural effusion, and high fatality rates.
  • Gastrointestinal anthrax is rare in humans, causing abdominal pain, vomiting, and bloody diarrhoea, while injection anthrax causes extensive oedema without eschar and may lead to septicemia.
  • Diagnosis involves examination of the lesion fluid, blood, or stool for large gram-positive rods.
  • Culture on blood agar produces nonhemolytic gray-white colonies with a ground-glass appearance. Colonies may display curved, hair-like projections resembling a Medusa head.
  • Culture smears reveal bacilli aligned end to end in long chains, with ends that are either truncated or concave and slightly swollen, giving the chain a characteristic bamboo stick appearance as shown below.
  • Capsule detection using M'Fadyean methylene blue stain appears as below.
  • Immunofluorescence, PCR for toxin genes, or ELISA for antibodies can also be used for diagnosis.
  • Control measures include safe disposal of animal carcasses, decontamination of animal products, protective equipment for handlers, and vaccination of domestic animals and high-risk individuals, as spores persist in soil for decades.

Explanation of other options:

Yersinia pestis (Option B): Yersinia pestis is a Gram-negative, nonmotile rod showing distinct bipolar staining with special stains, growing as a facultative anaerobe producing grey to white, opaque colonies without hemolysis. It has a mixed amino acid capsule. Clinically, it presents mainly as bubonic plague with sudden high fever and painful enlarged lymph nodes, septicemic plague with rapid progression to septic shock, coagulopathy, multi-organ failure, and gastrointestinal symptoms, or pneumonic plague, which causes severe respiratory distress and hemoptysis, either from direct inhalation (primary) or secondary spread from bubonic plague.

Clostridium perfringens (Option C): Clostridium perfringens is an anaerobic, spore-forming bacillus and produces large, raised colonies, sometimes with a double zone of β-hemolysis on blood agar. Clinically, it causes rapidly spreading myonecrosis or gas gangrene, characterised by tissue necrosis, crepitus, foul-smelling discharge, systemic toxicity, and shock.

Chlamydia trachomatis (Option D): Chlamydia trachomatis is an obligate intracellular bacterium with a biphasic developmental cycle, alternating between the small infectious elementary body and the larger replicative reticulate body, and forming compact intracytoplasmic inclusions containing glycogen. It exhibits Gram-negative-like cell wall structure without typical peptidoglycan, stains purple with Giemsa in the EB form, and is inhibited by sulfonamides. Clinically, it causes a range of human diseases, including trachoma, inclusion conjunctivitis, and nongonococcal urethritis.

questions.text: A 32 year old farmer presents with high grade fever, severe myalgia, and redness of the eyes. Investigations reveal elevated bilirubin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features of high-grade fever, severe myalgia, and conjunctivitis in a farmer, along with jaundice, is Weil's syndrome.

  • Leptospirosis is a zoonotic infection caused by pathogenic Leptospira species, with clinical manifestations ranging from asymptomatic illness to severe, potentially fatal disease.
  • In mild cases, it presents with nonspecific symptoms such as fever, headache, myalgia, and conjunctival suffusion, while severe disease, known as Weil's syndrome, is marked by jaundice, renal dysfunction, hemorrhagic tendencies, and multi-organ involvement.
  • Pulmonary haemorrhage, with or without jaundice, is now recognised as a significant manifestation of severe disease.
  • The causative organisms are thin, coiled, highly motile spirochetes with hooked ends and two periplasmic flagella. They are poorly stained but can be visualised using dark-field microscopy or silver impregnation techniques.
  • Epidemiologically, leptospirosis occurs worldwide but is more frequent in tropical and subtropical areas, especially in environments with poor hygiene.
  • Rodents, particularly rats, are the main reservoirs, though domestic and farm animals may also carry infection.
  • Transmission occurs through direct contact with urine, blood, or tissues of infected animals, or indirectly via contaminated soil and water, with the organisms surviving in moist environments for months.
  • Occupational exposure is common in veterinarians, farmers, sewage workers, and fishermen, while recreational water activities also pose risks.
  • Pathogenesis begins when leptospires penetrate abraded skin, conjunctiva, or mucosa, spreading hematogenously to multiple organs.
  • The illness is biphasic: the septicemic phase, lasting about 3-10 days, is characterised by fever, myalgia, headache, abdominal pain, and conjunctival suffusion, with organisms detectable in blood and CSF.
  • The immune phase follows with antibody production, during which organisms localise in tissues, especially the kidney, liver, and CNS, and are excreted in urine.
  • The phases and relevant investigations in each stage are shown below,
  • Severe disease may result in jaundice, renal failure, pulmonary haemorrhage, myocarditis, pancreatitis, and meningitis.

Explanation of other options:

Brucellosis (Option A): Brucella infects humans through ingestion of contaminated milk, inhalation of droplets, or contact with infected animal tissues, with an incubation period of 1-4 weeks. The illness begins insidiously with fever, malaise, sweats, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and sometimes hepatitis. While generalised symptoms usually resolve in weeks to months, localised lesions may persist.

Malaria (Option C): Malaria typically presents with fever and flu-like illness, with Plasmodium falciparum infections being the most severe and potentially fatal. Clinical features include periodic paroxysms of chills, high fever, and sweating, often accompanied by headache, nausea, and vomiting, with severe cases leading to complications such as cerebral involvement, jaundice, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and renal damage.

Enteric fever (Option D): Enteric fever caused by Salmonella typhi presents after an incubation of 10-14 days with fever, malaise, headache, myalgia, constipation, and sometimes bradycardia. Rose spots, though uncommon, are characteristic cutaneous findings. In the pre-antibiotic era, complications like intestinal haemorrhage and perforation were common with high mortality.

questions.text: A 19 year old college student presents with sudden onset fever, headache, vomiting, and a rapidly spreading purpuric rash. He appears confused, and his BP is measured to be 80/50 mmHg, HR 120/min, and Temp 39.5°C. On examination, he has petechiae and purpura over his lower limbs and trunk. He succumbs to his illness, and an autopsy is carried out. The gross specimen of the brain is shown below. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely causative pathogen in a patient with features of meningitis and petechial rashes progressing to shock and a gross specimen of the brain showing pus in the subarachnoid space is Neisseria meningitidis.

  • Neisseria are aerobic, Gram-negative, nonmotile, kidney-shaped diplococci arranged in pairs.
  • They can be cultured on sheep blood agar, chocolate agar, and selective media such as Thayer-Martin agar, which contains antibiotics to inhibit commensal organisms.
  • Colonies are convex, glistening, and mucoid, measuring 1-5 mm, with species variations in pigmentation and texture.
  • In N. meningitidis, at least 13 serogroups exist, with A, B, C, X, Y, and W-135 most important in human disease.
  • The capsule, composed of polysaccharides, aids immune evasion, while outer membrane proteins (Por A, Por B) and opacity proteins (Opa) contribute to virulence by interacting with host cells.
  • Lipooligosaccharide endotoxin, especially its lipid A, causes severe toxic effects.
  • Pathogenesis begins in the nasopharynx, where organisms adhere via pili and may remain asymptomatic or progress to invasive meningococcal disease (IMD).
  • Bacteremia can lead to meningitis or meningococcemia, presenting with fever, headache, vomiting, photophobia, stiff neck, and sometimes rapid progression to coma.
  • In meningococcemia, numerous small blood vessels across various organs undergo thrombosis, accompanied by surrounding infiltration and petechial bleeding.
  • Fulminant cases may involve hemorrhagic rash, DIC, shock, and Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome due to adrenal haemorrhage.
  • Lesions may also occur in the heart, joints, skin, and meninges, where thrombosis and purulent exudate develop.
  • Diagnosis involves blood and CSF cultures, Gram staining showing Gram-negative diplococci within leukocytes, and growth on selective media.
  • Serological tests measure antibodies to meningococcal polysaccharides.
  • Prevention includes vaccines targeting epidemic serogroups, chemoprophylaxis of close contacts with rifampin, ciprofloxacin, or ceftriaxone, and public health measures such as reducing crowding.

Explanation of other options:

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option A): Streptococcus pneumoniae is a Gram-positive spherical bacterium that typically appears in pairs or chains. Clinically, pneumococcal pneumonia begins abruptly with fever, chills, pleuritic chest pain, and bloody or rusty sputum, with bacteremia occurring in up to one-fifth of cases. Complications include empyema, meningitis, endocarditis, and septic arthritis. The presence of petechial rashes is more consistent with Neisseria meningitidis infection.

Haemophilus influenzae type B (Option B): Haemophilus influenzae type b typically spreads through the respiratory tract and can extend locally to involve the sinuses or middle ear, causing otitis media and sinusitis. It is also responsible for bronchitis and pneumonia, especially in individuals with impaired mucociliary clearance, and may lead to severe conditions such as septic arthritis, meningitis in children, or obstructive laryngotracheitis with epiglottitis.

Listeria monocytogenes (Option D): Exposure to Listeria monocytogenes in food may cause no illness or only a brief, mild febrile gastroenteritis with fever, chills, myalgia, abdominal pain, and diarrhoea, usually appearing 6-48 hours after ingestion. In immunocompromised individuals, it can progress to meningitis, meningoencephalitis, bacteremia, or rarely localised infections.

questions.text: A 35 year old man presents with a 2 week history of low grade fever, nonproductive cough, weight loss, and fatigue. Chest X ray shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with patchy infiltrates. A lactophenol cotton blue mount from the sputum culture appears as below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features of low-grade fever, cough, and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, along with lactophenol cotton blue staining showing numerous tuberculate macroconidia, are suggestive of histoplasmosis.

  • Histoplasmosis is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic soil fungus found worldwide that grows in soil enriched with bird or bat droppings.
  • Infection occurs through inhalation of conidia, which convert to yeast inside macrophages, spreading to reticuloendothelial organs.
  • Most cases are asymptomatic, but heavy exposure or immunosuppression can cause acute pulmonary disease with fever, chills, myalgias, cough, hilar lymphadenopathy, and pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Chronic and disseminated forms present with granulomas, necrosis, mucocutaneous ulcers, hepatosplenomegaly, and anaemia.
  • In culture below 37°C, H. capsulatum forms slow-growing brown mould colonies producing microconidia and macroconidia, while at 37°C or in tissue, it exists as small yeast cells within macrophages.
  • Radiographic findings may show calcified nodules, and reactivation is common in damaged lungs.
  • Treatment includes supportive care for mild disease, itraconazole for moderate cases, and amphotericin B for severe or disseminated infection, though relapses can occur, especially in AIDS patients requiring long-term therapy.
  • Epidemiologically, the highest incidence is in the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys, with infection linked to exposure to contaminated soil or guano.

Explanation of other options:

Pulmonary tuberculosis (Option A): Tuberculosis can affect nearly every organ system, leading to varied symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, weight loss, fever, and night sweats. Pulmonary disease often presents with chronic cough and hemoptysis in advanced stages, while meningitis or urinary tract involvement may occur even without lung signs. In cases of bloodstream spread, miliary tuberculosis develops, producing lesions across multiple organs and carrying a high risk of mortality. On ZN staining, red bacilli against a blue background can be seen.

Coccidioidomycosis (Option C): Most of the individuals infected with Coccidioides immitis remain asymptomatic, while the rest develop a self-limited flu-like illness known as valley fever, with fever, malaise, cough, headache, and arthralgia. Some also show hypersensitivity reactions such as rash or erythema nodosum. Radiological findings often include hilar lymphadenopathy with pulmonary infiltrates, pneumonia, pleural effusions, or nodules. Staining with H&E, PAS, or GMS can help to visualise the endospores.

Blastomycosis (Option D): Blastomycosis usually begins in the lungs, presenting with pulmonary infiltrates and symptoms similar to other respiratory infections, such as fever, malaise, cough, night sweats, and myalgias, though chronic pneumonia may also occur. Disseminated disease often affects the skin, producing verrucous granulomatous lesions with central scarring, as well as the bones, genitourinary tract, and central nervous system. Microscopic examination reveals broad-based budding as shown below.

questions.text: Group A Streptococcus is the most common cause of bacterial pharyngitis in school-aged children. Which of the following bacterial components is primarily responsible for its attachment to fibronectin on the epithelial lining of the pharynx?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the given options, the lipoteichoic acid of the Group A streptococcus is responsible for its attachment to fibronectin on the epithelial lining of the pharynx.

  • Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A streptococcus) attaches to the pharyngeal epithelium using surface pili coated with lipoteichoic acid, while fibronectin on epithelial cells likely serves as the binding ligand for this lipoteichoic acid, facilitating adherence and colonisation.
  • Gram-positive cell walls are rich in teichoic and teichuronic acids, which may form up to half the dry weight of the wall and significantly contribute to its negative charge.
  • These acids exist as wall teichoic acid (linked to peptidoglycan) or lipoteichoic acid (linked to membrane glycolipids), forming a polyanionic network that influences elasticity, porosity, and electrostatic properties.
  • Teichoic acids serve as major surface antigens, sometimes bearing specific determinants like the Forssman antigen, and in Streptococcus pyogenes, they associate with M protein fibrils to aid bacterial attachment to host cells.
  • Additionally, Gram-positive walls may contain polysaccharides made of neutral or acidic sugars, although their precise origin is uncertain.
  • The differentiating features of gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria are summarised in the table and illustration below.

Explanation of other options:

Capsule (Option A): Bacteria produce extracellular polysaccharide material called glycocalyx, which may appear as a capsule when firmly attached or as a slime layer when loosely associated. Capsules protect bacteria from phagocytosis and enhance virulence.

Flagella (Option B): Bacterial flagella function as helical rotors that enable motility by rotating through proton or ion-driven motors, allowing the cell to swim in liquid environments. They facilitate chemotaxis, where cells adjust movement toward attractants or away from repellents.

Lipoprotein (Option D): Lipoprotein in Gram-negative bacteria is a unique protein that links the outer membrane with the peptidoglycan layer. Its main role is to stabilise the outer membrane and firmly attach it to the underlying peptidoglycan layer.

questions.text: A child presents with intense perianal itching, especially at night. On examination, thread like white worms are seen in the perianal region, and the microscopic examination is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely causative organism, based on the history of perianal itching and microscopic examination revealing oval-shaped eggs flattened on one side, is suggestive of Enterobius vermicularis.

  • Enterobius vermicularis (Pinworm) is an intestinal nematode characterised by pointed or curved posterior ends.
  • It most commonly affects children and occurs more often in temperate climates. Infection is caused by ingestion of eggs, often through self-contamination, with the main symptom being nocturnal perianal itching due to egg deposition.
  • Scratching facilitates hand-to-mouth transmission.
  • Diagnosis is typically made using the Scotch Tape test, where eggs are collected from the perianal region and examined microscopically.
  • Eggs are football-shaped, with a thin shell, and may show larvae inside. Small adult worms may also be detected in stool ova and parasite examination.
  • Treatment includes pyrantel pamoate or mebendazole, and prevention requires washing bed linens, towels, and clothes in hot water to avoid reinfection.
  • The parasite primarily inhabits the lumen of the cecum and colon and is distributed worldwide, especially in temperate areas.

Explanation of other options:

Ancylostoma duodenale (Option B): Ancylostoma duodenale is a hookworm with each female able to release thousands of eggs daily, which hatch in faeces and produce larvae capable of surviving in moist soil, penetrating skin (commonly feet and ankles), and maturing into adults in the small intestine. Clinically, infection may present as ground itch with erythema and pruritus at the entry site, and intestinal disease marked by abdominal discomfort, diarrhoea, iron deficiency, and severe anaemia due to blood loss from attachment of worms to villi using buccal teeth. The egg appears as shown below.

Trichuris trichura (Option C): Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) is an intestinal nematode with slender anterior end and a thicker posterior end, giving it a whip-like appearance. Infection occurs after ingestion of embryonated eggs from contaminated food, with larvae hatching in the small intestine and maturing in the colon. Clinically, light infections may be asymptomatic, while heavier worm loads can cause abdominal pain, distention, diarrhea, bloody stools, cramps, tenesmus, rectal prolapse, and occasionally appendicitis. Eggs of trichuris trichura with distinct polar plugs appear as shown below.

Ascaris lumbricoides (Option D): Ascaris lumbricoides is a large intestinal roundworm and infection occurs when eggs are ingested, hatch in the duodenum, and larvae migrate via the bloodstream to the lungs before being swallowed back into the intestine, where adults mature and females release up to 200,000 eggs daily. Clinically, heavy infections can cause intestinal or biliary obstruction, abdominal pain, vomiting, or bowel perforation, while larval migration through the lungs may result in pneumonitis and Loeffler's syndrome with cough, eosinophilia, and pulmonary infiltrates. The image below shows mamillated eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides.

questions.text: A child presents with painful vesicular lesions near the mouth. Tzanck smear reveals multinucleated giant cells with intranuclear inclusions. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of painful vesicular lesions with multinucleated giant cells on Tzank smear is suggestive of oropharyngeal lesions caused by Herpes simplex virus.

  • Herpes simplex virus (HSV) grow rapidly, are cytolytic, and cause latent infections in nerve cells with frequent recurrences.
  • HSV is responsible for diseases such as gingivostomatitis, keratoconjunctivitis, encephalitis, genital herpes, and neonatal infections.
  • Two main types exist: HSV-1, classically spread via saliva, and HSV-2, usually transmitted sexually or from mother to newborn.
  • Histopathology shows ballooning cells, Cowdry type A inclusions, chromatin margination, and multinucleated giant cells.
  • HSV transmission occurs by direct contact with secretions from infected individuals. The virus enters through mucosal surfaces or broken skin, replicates locally, and spreads retrogradely via axons to ganglia, where latency is established: trigeminal for oropharyngeal HSV and sacral for genital HSV.
  • Primary infections are usually mild or asymptomatic, but may occasionally cause systemic disease. In immunocompromised hosts, dissemination can result in encephalitis or organ involvement.
  • Reactivation is triggered by stress, fever, trauma, or UV light, leading to recurrent infections at mucosal or skin sites.
  • Oropharyngeal disease is common in young children, presenting with fever, sore throat, gingivostomatitis, vesicles, and lymphadenopathy. Recurrences appear as herpes labialis (cold sores) as shown below.
  • Genital Herpes is usually caused by HSV-2, but HSV-1 can also cause it. Primary infections may be severe and painful, lasting up to 3 weeks with systemic symptoms. Recurrences are shorter and milder, sometimes asymptomatic but still infectious.
  • Skin Infections occur in areas with broken skin. Examples include herpetic whitlow seen on fingers and herpes gladiatorum seen in wrestlers. Severe disease can develop in eczema patients.
  • PCR is highly sensitive and specific, especially for CNS involvement.
  • Viral Isolation through culture from lesions, respiratory samples, or fluids. Identification is done via neutralization, immunofluorescence, or DNA analysis.
  • Tzanck smear show multinucleated giant cells with intracellular inclusions as shown below.

Explanation of other options:

Cytomegalovirus (Option A): In immunocomptenent hosts, CMV infection is often asymptomatic or presents as a mild heterophil-negative mononucleosis with possible subclinical hepatitis In immunocompromised individuals, CMV causes severe disease such as pneumonia, colitis, retinitis, or disseminated infection, with frequent reactivation in transplant recipients and AIDS patients. Microscopy findings in viral isolation show swollen translucent cells with large intranuclear inclusions, giving the characteristic owl-eye appearance as shown below.

Varicella-zoster virus (Option C): Varicella typically presents after an incubation period of 10-21 days with malaise, fever, and a rash that begins on the trunk and spreads to the face, limbs, and oral mucosa, showing lesions in different stages such as macules, papules, vesicles, and crusts. While usually mild in children, complications such as encephalitis, neonatal disease, and pneumonia may occur, with immunocompromised patients at risk for severe disseminated infections. In stained preparations made from scrapings or swabs taken from the base of vesicles (Tzanck smear), multinucleated giant cells can be observed. The given description of lesions is more consistent with herpes simplex virus infection.

Molluscum contagiosum virus (Option D): Molluscum contagiosum presents as small, pink, wart-like lesions that are often umbilicated and occur on the face, arms, trunk, and buttocks, but rarely on palms, soles, or mucous membranes. The lesions may itch, persist for up to two years, and can spread by scratching or contact, with genital lesions sometimes becoming inflamed or ulcerated. It is more common in children and immunocompromised individuals, especially those with AIDS, and while the disease usually resolves spontaneously, second attacks are frequent. The lesions appear as shown below.

questions.text: A male patient presents with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. Microscopic examination of bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid shows septate hyphae with acute-angle dichotomous branching. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features of fever, cough, and hemoptysis, along with microscopic examination revealing acute angle dichotomous branching, is aspergillosis.

  • Aspergillosis is a spectrum of diseases caused by several Aspergillus species, most commonly A. fumigatus.
  • These moulds produce abundant airborne conidia, which, when inhaled, can trigger allergic responses in atopic individuals or cause invasive disease in immunocompromised hosts such as those with leukaemia, stem cell transplants, or corticosteroid therapy.
  • In the lungs, alveolar macrophages usually destroy the conidia, but in compromised hosts, the spores germinate into hyphae that invade tissues and blood vessels, leading to aspergillomas or disseminated infection.
  • Clinically, aspergillosis presents in three main forms:
    • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, which resembles asthma with eosinophilia, chest infiltrates, and recurrent symptoms.
    • Aspergilloma or colonisation, where fungal balls develop in pre-existing lung cavities or colonise areas such as the sinuses, ear, cornea, or nails, often causing cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss.
    • Invasive aspergillosis, a severe condition marked by fever, cough, dyspnea, and hemoptysis, with hyphal invasion of vessels causing thrombosis, infarction, necrosis, and possible spread to the gastrointestinal tract, kidneys, liver, brain, or skin.
  • Diagnosis is made by microscopy and culture of respiratory or biopsy specimens, which reveal septate, dichotomously branching hyphae as shown below
  • Circulating galactomannan or β-glucan assays aid in diagnosing invasive disease.
  • Treatment varies by form and includes itraconazole or amphotericin B along with corticosteroids or cromoglycate for allergic forms.

Explanation of other options:

Mucormycosis (Option A): Mucormycosis most often presents as rhinocerebral disease, beginning with inhalation of spores into the nasal passages, leading to rapid spread into sinuses, eyes, cranial bones, and brain, causing oedema, bloody nasal discharge, orbital cellulitis, and tissue necrosis from vascular invasion. Morphologically, the fungi appear as broad hyphae with irregular branching, uneven thickness, and sparse septations, growing quickly in culture to form fluffy cotton-like colonies.

Histoplasmosis (Option B): Histoplasmosis is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic fungus that exists as mould in the environment and converts to small, oval yeast cells in tissues, often found within macrophages. Clinically, most infections are asymptomatic, but acute pulmonary disease can present with flu-like symptoms, hilar lymphadenopathy, and pulmonary infiltrates, while disseminated disease occurs in immunocompromised patients, leading to systemic involvement with high mortality. Morphologically, the mould form appears as hyaline septate hyphae with both microconidia and macroconidia with distinctive projection,s as shown below.

Candidiasis (Option D): Candidiasis presents with a range of clinical features, including superficial infections such as thrush on the tongue or oral mucosa, vulvovaginitis, intertriginous lesions in moist skin folds, and systemic disease that can involve organs like the kidneys, heart, and eyes, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. Morphologically, Candida species grow as oval budding yeast cells,, produce pseudohyphae when budding cells fail to detach as shown below.

questions.text: A middle-aged man from a tropical region presents with progressive swelling of the lower limb. A peripheral blood smear is shown below. What is the most likely cause of his limb swelling?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of progressive swelling of the lower limb, along with peripheral smear showing sheathed microfilaria with absent nuclei at the tail tip, is suggestive of Wuchereria Bancrofti infection, which causes lymphatic obstruction.

  • Wuchereria bancrofti is a filarial nematode transmitted by the Culex mosquitoes.
  • Human infection begins when infective larvae are introduced through a mosquito bite, after which the larvae migrate to lymphatic vessels in the arms, legs, or groin, where they mature.
  • Within 3–12 months, adult worms reproduce, releasing sheathed microfilariae into circulation.
  • These microfilariae are diagnostic, infect mosquitoes during feeding, and develop into infective third-stage larvae in the insect.
  • Adult worms can persist for up to 10 years and depend on bacterial endosymbionts for metabolism and reproduction.
  • The infection is endemic in tropical and subtropical regions, including Africa, Asia, and the Western Pacific.
  • Clinically, some individuals remain asymptomatic despite circulating microfilariae, while others develop acute symptoms such as fever, lymphangitis, lymphadenitis, chills, and recurrent febrile episodes.
  • Progression can cause lymph node enlargement, tissue thickening, and obstruction of lymph flow, leading to chronic lymphedema and elephantiasis. (Options A, C, and D ruled out)
  • Complications include bacterial superinfections, abscesses, ascites, and pleural effusions, while Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia (TPE) results from immune hyperresponsiveness with nocturnal cough, breathlessness, weight loss, and marked eosinophilia.
  • Diagnosis involves detecting microfilariae in blood smears stained with Giemsa, with both nocturnal and subperiodic periodicity influencing timing.
  • Buff coat films, membrane-filtration, and antigen detection methods also aid diagnosis, while PCR and serology for antifilarial antibodies are useful for confirmation.
  • Treatment targets microfilariae, as chronic lymphatic damage is irreversible. Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) is the drug of choice, often combined with ivermectin or albendazole
  • The other microfilariae pathogenic to man include Brugia malayi, Loa loa, Mansonella perstans, Mansonella ozzardi, and Onchocerca volvulus. The differentiating features are summarised in the flowchart and table below.

questions.text: A patient presents with chronic meningitis. Laboratory findings reveal Gram-positive, filamentous branching bacteria which are weakly acid-fast with modified Ziehl Neelsen (ZN) stain. The paraffin bait technique is used to isolate the organism. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features of chronic meningitis in a patient with a weakly acid-fast filamentous organism isolated with the paraffin bait technique are suggestive of Nocardia asteroides infection.

  • Nocardia species are aerobic, Gram-positive, catalase-positive bacteria that produce urease and appear in clinical specimens as filamentous, hyphae-like branching organisms.
  • They produce branching substrates and aerial filaments that fragment into coccobacillary cells. Their cell walls contain shorter-chained mycolic acids compared to mycobacteria, making them weakly acid-fast, retaining carbolfuchsin when decolourised with dilute sulfuric acid, as shown below.
  • Human infection begins through inhalation, typically presenting as subacute to chronic pulmonary disease that can spread to the brain or skin.
  • Importantly, these organisms are not transmitted person-to-person.
  • Nocardiosis usually occurs as an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients, including those on corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, or with AIDS, transplants, or alcoholism.
  • Pulmonary nocardiosis is the main presentation due to inhalation exposure, manifesting with fever, night sweats, weight loss, chest pain, and cough.
  • Radiologic findings can include infiltrates, multifocal nodules, or cavities. Abscess formation is typical, and hematogenous spread may involve the brain, causing abscesses and diverse neurological symptoms, or other organs like the skin, kidneys, and eyes.
  • Diagnostic laboratory tests rely on specimens such as sputum, pus, cerebrospinal fluid, or biopsy samples. The paraffin bait technique is an effective method of isolation of Nocardia.
  • Cultures readily grow on standard laboratory media, whereas serological tests are not useful.
  • The treatment of choice is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

Explanation of other options:

Actinomyces israeli (Option A): Actinomyces are aerotolerant organisms that, on Gram stain appear as short, club-shaped or long, thin, beaded filaments that may be branched or unbranched. Some strains grow slowly, producing colonies resembling molar teeth. Clinically, actinomycosis is a chronic suppurative and granulomatous infection causing pyogenic lesions with sinus tracts that discharge sulfur granules, and it can present as cervicofacial disease known as lumpy jaw, thoracic involvement with pulmonary destruction and chest wall sinus formation, or abdominal disease often following a ruptured appendix or ulcer. The following image shows sulfur granules seen in actinomyces infection

Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Option B): Mycobacterium tuberculosis appears in tissues as slender, straight rods. Due to their lipid-rich cell walls, they do not stain well with routine dyes but are identified by acid-fast staining, particularly the Ziehl-Neelsen method, with fluorochrome stains like auramine and rhodamine enhancing visualisation. Appearance on ZN staining is shown below. Clinically, primary infection is marked by acute exudative lesions spreading to lymph nodes, often healing with caseation and calcification (Ghon lesion), while reactivation tuberculosis produces chronic granulomatous disease with tubercles, caseation, and fibrosis.

Cryptococcus neoformans (Option D): Cryptococcus neoformans is a spherical budding yeast surrounded by a thick polysaccharide capsule, and produces whitish mucoid colonies in culture. Clinically, it most often causes chronic meningitis, and it may also produce lesions in the skin, lungs, or other organs. India ink staining can be used to delineate the capsule, as shown below.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4350862/

questions.text: In a village, several people develop dysentery after consuming raw milk. Laboratory examination of stool samples reveals: Gram-negative, curved rods with predominant polymorphonuclear infiltration. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the given clinical features of dysentery after consuming raw milk and microscopic findings of Gram-negative curved rods, the most likely causative organism is Campylobacter jejuni.

  • Campylobacter jejuni is a frequent cause of bacterial gastroenteritis and can also cause systemic infections.
  • The organisms are curved, comma- or S-shaped, Gram-negative rods that are motile with a single polar flagellum.
  • Colonies vary in appearance, often grey or watery, and are oxidase- and catalase-positive but do not ferment carbohydrates.
  • The bacteria contain lipopolysaccharides with endotoxin activity and may release toxins, though their disease role is not well defined.
  • Infection typically follows the ingestion of contaminated food or water, or contact with animals, especially poultry, and requires a relatively small infectious dose.
  • The organisms invade the intestinal lining, causing inflammation and diarrhoea, which may be bloody, accompanied by abdominal pain, and ever.
  • In some cases, bacteremia or complications like Guillain-Barre syndrome or reactive arthritis can occur.
  • Diagnosis relies on stool specimens.
  • Gram-stained smears may show characteristic 'gull-wing' shaped rods with darting motility.
  • A definitive diagnosis is made through culture on selective media under microaerophilic conditions.
  • Rectal swabs may also be used, and if C. fetus is suspected, cephalosporin-free media with incubation at 36-37°C are recommended.

Explanation of other answers:

Clostridium perfringens (Option A): Clostridium perfringens are large spore-forming Gram-positive rods. Clinically, they cause gas gangrene through contaminated wounds, leading to crepitus, necrosis, foul-smelling discharge, and possible death, while ingestion of contaminated meat results in a short-lived diarrheal illness without fever or vomiting.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option B): Staphylococcus aureus appears microscopically as Gram-positive cocci arranged in clusters. Clinically, it produces localised infections such as abscesses, as well as systemic diseases including bacteremia, endocarditis, osteomyelitis, pneumonia, food poisoning with rapid-onset diarrhoea and vomiting, and toxic shock syndrome marked by sudden fever, hypotension, rash, and multiorgan involvement.

Vibrio parahaemolyticus (Option C): Vibrio parahaemolyticus is a halophilic, Gram-negative rod that thrives in saltwater and grows on TCBS agar, producing green colonies due to the lack of sucrose fermentation. Clinically, it causes acute gastroenteritis after ingestion of raw or undercooked seafood, presenting with watery diarrhoea, abdominal cramps, nausea, and fever.

choices.text: Septate hyphae with 4-5 microns in width

questions.text: A patient presents with a long-standing swelling and discharging sinuses on the foot as shown below. The discharge contains black granules. What is the most likely finding on the KOH mount?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above clinical picture of long-standing swelling and discharging sinuses on the foot with black granules is suggestive of eumyectoma caused by Madurella mycetomatis, which has septate hyphae that are 4-5 microns in width.

  • Mycetoma is a chronic subcutaneous infection caused by traumatic implantation of fungi (eumycetoma) or actinomycetes (actinomycetoma) from soil.
  • It is characterised by progressive swelling, draining sinuses, and the presence of granules that represent colonies of the infecting organism.
  • While both forms share similar clinical features, actinomycetoma tends to be more aggressive, spreading from subcutaneous tissues into underlying muscle, though treatment differs between the two types.
  • The fungal agents of mycetoma include P. boydii, M. mycetomatis, Madurella grisea, E. jeanselmei, and Acremonium falciforme.
  • The colour and nature of the granules can distinguish these species:

The granules of M. mycetomatis are hard and compact, containing broad septate hyphae measuring 3-5 µm in width, with the hyphae appearing irregularly distorted and enlarged at the periphery. (Option B ruled out)

Explanation of other answers:

Pseudohyphae (Option A): In a KOH preparation, Candida is identified by the presence of yeast cells or pseudohyphae. The yeast appears as oval budding cells, while pseudohyphae are elongated chains formed when buds grow but do not detach, showing constrictions at the septa. In C. albicans, both yeast cells and pseudohyphae may be seen, and unlike some other Candida species, it can also produce true hyphae.

Filamentous branching bacteria (Option D): Actinomyces are Gram-positive bacteria that show variable morphology, appearing as short club-shaped forms or elongated beaded filaments, which may be branched or unbranched. On agar, they can form colonies with a molar tooth appearance.
